Date/Time: You uploaded a feed document on June 18, 2025 at 5:00 PM (GMT)
Media Description:
One of the most unusual features of Excel is its support for writing formulas in multiple languages.

For some, this is one of the most nerve-wracking features ? since maintaining Excel sheets in different languages is way too confusing. And even though Excel will attempt to automatically translate the formulas to your default installation language, it won't be perfect ? especially when copy-pasting parts of a workbook in a different language.

If you ever run into this issue, be aware that there is a "Functions Translator" add-in in Excel that helps you with the formula translation and even provides a reference of the formula names in other languages.

I can see how Microsoft has tried its best to provide support for all languages possible. But honestly, it's unusual to have this multilingual support in formulas.

Why can't it be like programming languages?

What do you think? ?

#Excel #MicrosoftExcel #ExcelFunctions

Media Description:
Calculating a percentile X, based on two other percentiles for a lognormal distribution, sounds familiar?

That's right, in reserves estimation, when we have any two rough estimates of high / low / medium reserves values, and you need to estimate the unknown one (if you don't have a full probabilistic run at hand of course).

Here is a deep dive on calculating it in #Python using only #scipy and #numpy. Beyond the reserves estimation application itself, it is an interesting topic to understand a bit more about distributions and revisit some university topics ?

Also, here is the link to the notebook version: https://lnkd.in/esPhRWaX

- psst, you can run it in your browser if you use #codespaces without installing anything, the repo already has the #devcontainer in it.

Have you done this before, and if so, what did you use to calculate the unknown percentile? Let me know in the comments ?

Do you think you are done with your linear regression model? Not so fast...

Linear regression is a widely used statistical method for predicting a dependent variable based on one or more independent variables.

Even though it's a breeze to set up and run a linear regression model (in both R and Python), it's imperative to remember that the model's validity and reliability are contingent on meeting several key assumptions. 
 
Let's talk about them in this post ?

Implementing a "Well" Class in Python?. Intro to Object-Oriented Programming (OOP).

You might have heard about OOP before. It is a great way to encapsulate, abstract, and represent real-world entities in code. 

Here, I use a well-known object for those working in the O&G industry (and other engineering fields) to introduce OOP.

Even though some scary concepts ? are related to this subject (inheritance, polymorphism, abstraction/interfaces, design patterns, etc..), let's try to forget that for a little while, and let's get our hands dirty by implementing this "Well" Class!!

It's always interesting to see the use cases you've given to OOP in your engineering code! Feel free to comment below ?
